bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Marjorie Latta (Barstow) Greenbie, 1891-1976, was born in Jersey City, NJ. She received a B.A. from Cornell in 1912 and a Ph.D. from Yale in 1916 and taught English successively at the University of Kansas, Vassar College, and Mount Holyoke College. She wrote many books on American history, including American Saga and Lincoln's Daughters of Mercy. Her most popular book was My Dear Lady: The Story of Anna Ella Carroll, the Great, Unrecognized Member of Lincoln's Cabinet, about a key adviser to President Abraham Lincoln. Carroll gave Lincoln indispensable legal advice on his war powers under the Constitution and initiated the plan for the Tennessee River military campaign that geographically split the Confederacy.

Sydney Greenbie, 1889-1960, was born in the Dakota Territory. He was a life-long world traveler and began his career with a trip to Japan in 1917, where he became an English instructor in Kobe Higher Commercial School. In 1942, Greenbie was named special consultant on Far Eastern affairs to the Coordinator of Information and the War Department. He wrote many books, including Asia Unbound, American Boy in the Orient, and Good Neighbor Series on Latin America.

Sydney Greenbie and Marjorie Latta (Barstow) Greenbie were married in New York City on 24 May 1919. They co-authored a number of works, including This We Inherit, The General Was a Lady, Danger in Heaven, Hoofbeats to Heaven, The Aunty Mar Books, Suit with Red Lining, and Hoofbeats in the Canebrake.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Greenbie mss., 1950-1953, consists of correspondence and copies of correspondence of Marjorie Latta (Barstow) Greenbie, 1891-1976, and Sydney Greenbie, 1889-1960, authors, with John Donald Barnhart, editor of the Indiana Magazine of History; Herman B. Wells, President, Indiana University; Fenwick Thomas Reed, assistant to the President, Indiana University; Herman Thompson Briscoe, Dean, Indiana University; and Robert Gerald McMurtry, Director, Department of Lincolniana, Lincoln Memorial University, Harrogate, Tennessee, in regard to Professor Kenneth Powers Williams' article, "The Tennessee River Campaign and Anna Ella Carroll," which appeared in the Indiana Magazine of History, XLVI: [221]-48, September 1950 and to Sydney Greenbie's "Reply to Kenneth Williams," which appeared in the Lincoln Herald, LV: 37-41, Spring 1953.
